intro: Macraea crenata, commonly known as the African velvet tamarind, is a deciduous tree native to tropical Africa. It belongs to the family Fabaceae and is characterized by its compound leaves and showy, fragrant flowers. The tree produces long, woody pods that contain edible seeds, which are used in traditional medicine and cuisine. Its bark and leaves are also valued for their medicinal properties, including anti-inflammatory and antifungal effects. Macraea crenata is often found in dry savannas and is adapted to seasonal rainfall patterns.
